Description: Body sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice with cul and handle root; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black (mostly worn); added red band between two added white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of hindquarters with red patch and foreleg of possible feline to right; swastika, dot rosette and cross square filled with dots as filling ornament; below, at top of cul, two brown bands; black on handle root with red blob on upper left; below, two brown bands.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the animal as possibly a boar, however, the body form is not consistent with other boars depicted on Chian fine ware. Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a light-walled and big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 261, no. 518, pl. 67)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1554) (phase 2)
